title.narrative: Asycuda World 123

narrative.narrative: The GoDRC (DGDA) has initiated the migration from ASYCUDA++ Customs Management System to ASYCUDA World, a web base platform in partnership with UNCTAD. Many Customs offices in East DRC still on ASYCUDA ++ or are still using a manual system to clear goods. TMEA in partnership with the Directorate General of Customs (DGDA) and UNCTAD is supporting to fill the gap of the ASYCUDA World deployment in eastern DRC. The project is in line with TMEA’s goal to reduce transport costs and times on main corridors. The project will streamline Customs procedures for faster clearance with less paperwork, increase country’s tax revenue generated from taxes on trade, provided by the DGDA increased compliance and adoption of better risk-based approaches to controlling borders. The work of DGDA will be supported by UNCTAD who will provide installation, training and  maintenance support of ASYCUDA World.
TradeMark East Africa

title.narrative: Ruzizi II One Stop Border Post (OSBP) Infrastructure Upgrade

narrative.narrative: Ruzizi 2 border post carries most of the heavy trucks traffic between Rwanda and DRC, particularly to Bukavu. At Ruzizi 2 smaller-scale traders are underserved and prefer to use Ruzizi premier. Border offices on both sides of the border and the bridge will be upgraded. The offices will be supplied with water, power and appropriate office furniture. The current cross border market facility will be upgraded on the Bukavu side of the border to accommodate traders’ needs. This simple structure will facilitate commerce at the border post. Currently many traders are forced to sell on the side of the road as existing infrastructure is full. The road connecting the border post to the city of Bukavu is in a poor condition and in need of upgrade to reduce the damage to vehicles, as well as time and cost of moving goods along a relatively short distance. Under this programme the section of road that feeds in Ruzizi 2 border post (approximately 2.7km long each), will be upgraded including all necessary earthworks drainage. For safety reasons the road will also be fitted with electrical lighting. The bridge at Ruzizi 2 will also be rehabilitated.
TradeMark East Africa

title.narrative: Safe Trade  Rwanda Country Programme -Tech Interventions (COVID-19)

narrative.narrative:
Safe Trade Cluster 2 technology works will focus on three key broad intervention areas: 
1.	Regional Electronic Cargo and Driver Tracking System (RECDTS)
A digital-based solution that provides a trusted framework for sharing the mutually recognised EAC COVID-19 Test Certificates among Ministries of Health in the EAC, to facilitate movement of truck drivers across the region through elimination of multiple testing at entry points in the times of COVID-19. Support areas include;
a.	System development – including development of drivers, health, and enforcement officers mobile applications; geo-fencing of designated stop/rest areas along the major trade corridors in the EAC
b.	System integrations/interfaces to National Laboratory Systems. 
c.	System Infrastructure and operational support framework for the anchor platform (RECTS) - hosting support.
d.	Change management activities – sensitization/training of users (truck drivers, truck companies, health, and enforcement officers)

2.	Paperless border transactions
Enhancement of the SCT centralised platform to include automation of transit documents. This will limit the use of paper - a potential conduit of virus transmission, as well as limit human interaction in the times of COVID-19.

3.	Automatic identification and verification technologies (subject to availability of funds)
These will automate and further enhance clearance and release processes at border crossings, utilising technology to limit human interaction. These technologies will include;
a.	Smart gates. 
b.	Optical Character Recognition (OCR).
c.	Facial recognition. 
d.	Automatic number plate reader.
TradeMark East Africa

title.narrative: Support to Women Entrepreneurs

narrative.narrative:
The project specifically seeks to:
 (i) Increase access to information and trade support services: Small business owners (predominantly women) state that the several challenges including capacity needs, lack of professional services/skills, access to market information are hindrance to their ability to trade.  The project will aim to provide capacity in terms of skills and knowledge to enable women in selected value chains to trade formally, improve access finance and markets.  

 (ii)Increase trade value for women: According to studies, women trade in commodities with little or no value addition and are therefore disadvantaged as their returns on trade remain low. The project’s objective is to support women traders to access high value markets through trading in clusters/cooperatives and other groupings that support consolidation of resources and collective bargaining for cost reduction. The project will provide institutional capacity support to the Chamber of Women to enable it to provide much needed stewardship to women traders. 
The project with be implemented though a grant to Rwanda Women’s Chamber who are a national umbrella /apex representing women entrepreneurs.
TradeMark East Africa

title.narrative: Integrating Public-Private Sector Dialogue (PPD) for Trade and Investment

narrative.narrative:

title.narrative: Rwanda Utilities Regulatory Authority (RURA) Single Window System

narrative.narrative:
The Rwanda Utilities Regulatory Authority (RURA) was created in 2001 with the mission to regulate key public utilities namely: telecommunications network and/or telecommunications services, electricity, water, removal of waste products from residential or business premises, extraction and distribution of gas and transport of goods and persons.

RURA plays two critical trade functions: - the licensing and inspection of imported goods in regulated sectors such as electronics and allied goods; and the protection of Intellectual Property Rights (IPRs). It is within this context that TMEA is extending its support to RURA  to implement an ICT enabled solution that will focus on addressing how importers and exporters in RURA-regulated sectors comply with standards and requirements; how RURA can enforce regulations through inspections and verifications done in conjunction with other trade agencies such as Customs and Bureaus of Standards; and how RURA can ensure that fair competition in the Rwanda trade environment is maintained through IPR protection measures.

title.narrative: Rwanda Bureau of Standards Single Window System  (Phase 2)

narrative.narrative:
The Rwanda Standards Board (RSB) is a public National Standards Body established by the Government of Rwanda, whose mandate is to develop and publish National Standards, carry out research in the areas of standardisation, and to disseminate information on standards, technical regulations related to standards and conformity assessment, metrology for the setting up of measurement standards, among others.
In Phase 1, RSB collaborated with TMEA to design, develop and implement a Management Information Systems (MIS) and an Information Portal (IP). In Phase 2, TMEA plans to enhance the support provided in the initial phase and extend to other areas with the aim ensuring RSB’s system function seamlessly to guarantee robust and reliable system internally and externally. Phase 2 will comprise of the following:-
a)	Technical Assistant: conduct gap analysis, coordinate and support collection of data necessary and reporting for the project; also provide ICT support to agency staff and serve as the link between TMEA, government agencies and their stakeholders.   
b)	MIS Upgrade
i.	National Standards Division: Online sales elibrary, e-commenting, e-training certificates,
ii.	National Certification Division: e-certification
iii.	National Metrology Division: metrology
iv.	Corporate Services Division and DGs Office: IT and Estates support, document sharing
v.	Any identified gaps
c)	Laboratory Information Management System (LIMS)
i.	 Upgrade of Pharmaceutical component(Phase 1 of the LIMS upgrade)
ii.	Integration to Management Information System
d)	Change Management components (sensitization and training)
TradeMark East Africa

title.narrative: National Agricultural Export Development Board (NAEB) II

narrative.narrative:
National Agricultural Export Board (NAEB) is a department under the Ministry of Agriculture in Rwanda. The Board is charged with the responsibility of issuing Certificates of Quality as well as Certificates of Origin for individuals and companies exporting tea, coffee and horticulture. Their mandate includes testing and inspections on samples and consignments for export.

This project automates the process of acquiring trade documents in the export of tea, coffee and horticultural products.  While this automation happened in the first phase of the project, the second phase builds onto the initial development works to enhance and upgrade both the technology and workflows already automated. Particularly, the enhancements and upgrades will;

1.	Enable end to end automation and exchange of information between NAEB SWIFT and the ReSW to provide exporters of tea, coffee and horticulture full visibility of the entire clearance process.
2.	Integrate to a payment gateway to enable and facilitate online payments for Certificates of Origin; and 
3.	Integrate with the East Africa Exchange (EAX) in Rwanda to provide an online platform for NAEB stakeholders to access EAX services.
4.	Development of the horticulture module and training of internal and external stakeholders on this.
5.	Integration of NAEB to RALIS to allow seamless exchange of information as regards issuance of a Phytosanitary certificate for export of Tea, coffee, and horticultural products.
TradeMark East Africa

title.narrative: Elimination of Non-Tariff Barriers  (NTBs) and Trade Facilitation

narrative.narrative: Removing Non-Tariff Barriers (NTBs) is now a high priority in the EAC integration agenda. The East African Community (EAC) is a desired platform to advocate against NTBs that Rwanda is facing given the fact that EAC corridors (Northern and Central) and ports (Mombasa and Dar es Salaam) are of strategic importance to Rwanda’s exports and imports. In Rwanda, TradeMark East Africa has been supporting the elimination of NTBs to trade through the Ministry of Trade, Industry and EAC Affairs as the Chair and Secretariat to the National Monitoring Committee (NMC). The Rwanda NTB programme therefore aims to support Improvement of Mechanisms for Active Engagement on Elimination of Cross-Border NTB’s; Enhance operations of the Rwanda NMC for elimination of outstanding NTBs; Implementation of the EAC Time Bound Matrix on Elimination of NTBs and; Increase awareness on NMC activities and NTB elimination mechanisms.
TradeMark East Africa

title.narrative: Sanitary and Phytosanitary (SPS) measures

narrative.narrative: The Rwanda Sanitary and Phytosanitary (SPS) project is part of the wider Rwanda Standards and SPS programme aimed at developing and implementing interventions to address technical barriers to trade in industrial and agricultural goods. Interventions have been tailored towards improving services provided by the relevant Government of Rwanda conformity assessment bodies, and to increase private sector service provision on in enhancing compliance. The key outcome expected is Enhanced Private Sector Compliance with Standards and SPS Requirements. At the inception of the project there was no private body to offer certification to private standards in the agriculture sector to producers in Rwanda while at the same time imported services are expensive and inadequate to prepare producers for certification. TMEA Rwanda interventions will therefore be geared towards increasing service providers who will in turn facilitate compliance to international market-driven standards.

title.narrative: Rusizi II One Stop Border Post (OSBP)

narrative.narrative:
Rusizi II border post is located in the western part of Rwanda and is the main entrance and exit border between Rusizi and Bukavu trading areas used mainly by heavy trucks destined to and from to Bukavu. The border post has been characterised by old small infrastructure with no clear operational flow of goods and passenger handling. Unharmonized procedures that do not facilitate smooth flow of business at the border post. 

The Construction of a One Stop Border Post (OSBP) and implementation of integrated Border Management (IBM) at Rusizi II border will facilitate the smooth and efficient cross border movement of vehicles passengers between Rwanda and DRC Congo. It is planned that the modern border post will cater for the heavy truck traffic, smaller-scale traders and crossing passengers
TradeMark East Africa

title.narrative: Rusizi Port Facilities Construction

narrative.narrative:
The main component of the Lake Kivu Transport project is the construction of harbor facilities on Lake Kivu at Rubavu and Rusizi. The two districts are at the busiest border crossings between Rwanda and DRC and together represent about 70% of Rwanda’s total cross border trade volumes  . In addition to the construction of the harbor facilities, Transaction Advisory services will be provided to attract private sector investment for management of ports and barge operations and review the marine regulatory and institutional framework. Construction of the ports will kick-off in the FY2018-19 

Rubavu is situated on the northern end of the lake and is the main gateway for trade to Goma and the North Kivu province in the DRC. Rusizi is located in the Southern end of the lake and is the main gateway for trade towards Bukavu and the South Kivu province in the DRC. TMEA has constructed a Cross Border Market in Rusizi. 

TMEA has funded the construction of Cross Border Markets in Rubavu and Rusizi. Under the women in trade programme, a number of cooperatives based in the two districts were also supported to increase their competitiveness and so the selection of the two sites fits well into the overall TMEA Rwanda Cross Border Trade work.
TradeMark East Africa

title.narrative: Export Growth for Export Ready Businesses

narrative.narrative: The export capability programme for Tanzania will support the increase of market access of targeted horticulture products in both regional and international markets. In partnership with the Tanzania Horticulture Association (TAHA), the programme aims to spearhead the design of the Tanzania Horticulture Market Access Strategy (HIMAS) which will focus on identifying potential markets for Tanzania horticulture projects, identifying existing barriers within the sector, private sector competitiveness constraints and inefficiencies in market support infrastructure related to transport and logistics. In addition, the strategy will map out existing players and programmes and their potential role of the implementation of the strategy. Upon validation by the private and public sector, TAHA will embark on the coordination and implementation of the strategy. TMEA will leverage existing programmes implemented in the sector by TAHA in partnership with other development partners and support the implementation of interventions around building export capacities (standards compliance and other support services), addressing priority regulatory constraints, facilitating access to targeted market support infrastructure (cold chain, warehousing and aggregation), strengthening market linkages and access to market information.

title.narrative: Ministry of Livestock and  Fisheries Single Window System

narrative.narrative:
Ministry of Livestock and Fisheries is a Public institution in Tanzania. Its mission is to build and support the technical and professional capacity of local government authorities and the private sector to develop, manage, and regulate the livestock and fisheries resources sustainably.

The project aims to improve the Ministry’s efficiency by establishing an electronic platform to enable traders to electronically apply for trade documents related to Livestock, livestock products, Fish and fish products. The platform is intended to also provide a trading platform for livestock at the internal markets as well as monitor cattle inter-district movement through the issuance of cattle movement licenses. The platform intends to support 4 departments: diary department, meat department, fisheries department, and livestock department.

title.narrative: Ministry of Agriculture Single WIndow Phase II

narrative.narrative:
The Single Window Information for Trade (SWIFT) System (or Single Window) is a trade facilitation concept that enables international (cross-border) traders to submit regulatory documents at a single location and/or single entity. These documents typically include customs declarations, applications for import/export permits, and other supporting documents such as certificates of origin and trading invoices. The project supports automation of 13 crop boards, that are linked with the Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock and Fisheries, to automate their trade facilitation business processes and set up their trading regulations information portal. The crop boards are: Plant Health Services, Fertilizers Board, Tea Board, Coffee Board, Sisal Board, Pyrethrum Board, Cotton Board, Tanzania Pesticide Research Institute, and Tanzania Official Seed Certification Institute (TOSCI).

Project’s Key expected results include:
?	The 13 targeted crop boards improve competency in using the SWIFT;
?	Economic operators and trade agencies improve efficiency.
TradeMark East Africa

title.narrative: Tanzania Medicine and Medical Devices Authority - TMDA

narrative.narrative:
In 2014 TFDA in collaboration with TMEA developed an Integrated Management Information System (IMIS) for processing of registration of the regulated products, issuance import and export permits, and premises registration; and laboratory management.  However, TFDA has not been able to optimize use of all the automated processes which had been provided for access to applicants through the portal. The current accessible service has been limited to the application of import and export services due to myriad of challenges faced in deploying the other processes online. The transition of TFDA from the manual processes to using the online and automated processes has brought with it other needs that require to be addressed in order to continue promoting the uptake of the system. 

This project therefore intends to enhance the TFDA system to guarantee 100% end-to-end digital transactions of related processes in the operations and administration of trade documentations and border formalities carried out by TFDA as part of their regulatory mandate to protect the safety and health of Tanzanian and the wider East African Community citizens as well as facilitate trade.

title.narrative: Quality and Standards Programme

narrative.narrative: The existing standards frameworks in Tanzania faces challenges of policy, administrative, regulatory and enforcement nature. These challenges have hampered TBS's capability to offer quality service to its stakeholders; develop market-oriented standards; and foster the uptake and adoption of standards by the business community. The support will assist TBS in the following; 1.) Development of a training program on Standards, targeting MSMEs using conventional training methods suitable for businesses - using both analogue and digital platforms; 2.) Development of an integrated Standards, Quality, Metrology and Testing (iSQMT) system that will automate the key administrative processes used by TBS to offer services to its stakeholders; 3.) Development of a National Quality Policy Framework to establish guidelines and procedures in the development, administration, regulation and enforcement of standards in Tanzania; and 4.) Development of a standards harmonization and accreditation program to support TBS to domesticate regionally harmonized standards and also have their systems, processes and service delivery processes accredited.
TradeMark East Africa

title.narrative: Safe Trade  Uganda Country Programme -Tech Interventions (COVID19)

narrative.narrative:
Safe Trade Cluster 2 technology works will focus on three key broad intervention areas: 
1.	Regional Electronic Cargo and Driver Tracking System (RECDTS)
A digital-based solution that provides a trusted framework for sharing the mutually recognised EAC COVID-19 Test Certificates among Ministries of Health in the EAC, to facilitate movement of truck drivers across the region through elimination of multiple testing at entry points in the times of COVID-19. Support areas include;
a.	System development – including development of drivers, health, and enforcement officers mobile applications; geo-fencing of designated stop/rest areas along the major trade corridors in the EAC
b.	System integrations/interfaces to National Laboratory Systems. 
c.	System Infrastructure and operational support framework for the anchor platform (RECTS) - hosting support.
d.	Change management activities – sensitization/training of users (truck drivers, truck companies, health, and enforcement officers)

2.	Paperless border transactions

title.narrative: Gulu Logistics Hub

narrative.narrative:
The Gulu Trade Logistics Hub is expected to improve capacity of transport infrastructure in Northern Uganda to serve markets in South Sudan, Northern Uganda and parts of DRC; Efficient management of freight transport through Northern Uganda; Improve capacity to handle containers and other cargo in Gulu. 

The Hub will also provide for efficient Humanitarian Assistance; Reduction in poverty; and Increase in exports. This hub will serve the trade corridors of (i) Kampala – Gulu - Elegu/Nimule - Juba Trade Corridor; and  (ii) Gulu – Packwach Goli/Padea/Lia/Vura DRC Trade Corridor. 

Proposed developments include Container Yard; Railway Siding; Container Freight Station; Warehousing Complex; Vehicle holding area and traffic flows; access roads, Truck Stop (Parking); Administration building; Container light repair w/shop; Customs office; Perimeter wall; Security gate and guardhouse. 

The GLH will provide functions such as container and break-bulk, handling and storage facilities, space for stakeholders dealing with freight transport (freight forwarders, shippers and transport operators) and the provision of accompanying services such as customs inspections, tax payment, maintenance and repair, banking and information communication technology connections.
TradeMark East Africa

narrative.narrative:
Safe Trade Cluster 2 technology works will focus on three key broad intervention areas: 
1.	Regional Electronic Cargo and Driver Tracking System (RECDTS)
A digital-based solution that provides a trusted framework for sharing the mutually recognised EAC COVID-19 Test Certificates among Ministries of Health in the EAC, to facilitate movement of truck drivers across the region through elimination of multiple testing at entry points in the times of COVID-19. Support areas include;
a.	System development – including development of drivers, health, and enforcement officers mobile applications; geo-fencing of designated stop/rest areas along the major trade corridors in the EAC
b.	System integrations/interfaces to National Laboratory Systems. 
c.	System Infrastructure and operational support framework for the anchor platform (RECTS) - hosting support.
d.	Change management activities – sensitization/training of users (truck drivers, truck companies, health, and enforcement officers)

2.	Paperless border transactions

3.	Automatic identification and verification technologies (subject to availability of funds)
These will automate and further enhance clearance and release processes at border crossings, utilising technology to limit human interaction. These technologies will include;
a.	Smart gates. 
b.	Optical Character Recognition (OCR).
c.	Facial recognition.

title.narrative: Enhancing Market Access for Fresh Produce through Certification

narrative.narrative:
The stringent international standards and dynamic market requirements remain an increasing impediment to export market access. The volume of horticulture exports to the EU market dropped by 30 per cent from 4,143 tons in the year 2014 to 3672 tons in the year 2015. Specifically, the volume of fresh vegetables exports from Kenya reduced by 7% compared to 2014. This drop is partly attributed to inadequate skills in compliance and low capacity in quality management by small scale farmers to comply with stringent market requirements, weak traceability system and lack of information on new emerging markets.

title.narrative: Mombasa Trade and Logistics Hub

narrative.narrative:
The Coastal region, comprising of about 4 million people, faces significant development challenges leading to widespread unemployment and poverty of 38% and 59% respectively. These are the 2nd highest unemployment and poverty rates in the country after North Eastern region which is mostly semi-arid occurs in a region with abundant land and sea resources that have not been fully exploited due to various challenges thereby resulting in tension, unemployment and civil strife due to economic underdevelopment and increasing sense of marginalization. 

These challenges have been compounded by collapse of key economic drivers like agriculture and fisheries, low factor productivity and overreliance on primary agricultural production for subsistence and domestic markets.

The Trade and Logistics Cluster approach seeks to establish a vision for the Coastal region based on higher value productive activities and providing a pathway to help the region achieve the necessary structural transformation from low value subsistence agricultural production to higher productivity through manufacturing for export, value addition activities and development of backward and forward value chains. Initial scoping study done by TMEA using World Bank Geospatial planning model, identified agribusiness, Textiles and apparel, and fisheries as the three key sectors with huge growth potential to generate employment, earn foreign exchange through exports, create high value markets for local farmers and new opportunities for local small and Medium Enterprises.
TradeMark East Africa

title.narrative: Support to Public-Private Dialogue

narrative.narrative:
This project on integrating Public-Private Sector Dialogue (PPD) for Trade and Investment in Kenya, complements TMEA's Outcome 1 and 2 interventions and results relating to; 
•	Reduction in transport cost and time and Increased efficiency in private sector logistics services provision.
•	Enhanced Customs, Port and other trade-related agencies efficiency.
•	Reduction in tariffs, taxes and levies (including sub-national) and increased tax incentives.
•	Enhanced efficiency of the Bureau of Standards, and improve private sector compliance. 
•	Catalysing increase in exports, job creation (direct and indirect) and additional investment in targeted sectors in Kenya.

The programme will have one Lead coalition Partner, the Kenya Private Sector Alliance (KEPSA) a national private sector apex body working jointly with the Kenya Association of Manufacturers (KAM) and other PSOs, sector-based associations and Civil Society organisations. The Lead coalition Partner is the Key convenor of PPD forums, EABC’s focal point and a link to the regional programme.

title.narrative: Moyale Integrated Border Management

narrative.narrative:
The IBM Programme II  builds on the Strategy I IBM programme and incorporates lessons learnt. IBM II projects are located within the EAC region and at borders between the EAC and the Great Lakes, Horn of Africa and Southern Africa regions. The projects are aligned to Article 12 (1) and (2) of the TFA, which encourages customs administrations to cooperate and exchange information on matters promoting trader compliance. Given that the EAC has progressed through the adoption of a Customs Union, Common Market Protocol and recently the Single Customs Territory, it is best placed to advance these principles within the community and to extend it to its neighbours.  

The projects will be implemented by TMEA, jointly with the EAC Secretariat and OSBPs Lead Agencies, in collaboration with all the Government border agencies (Ministries, Departments and Agencies), National OSBPs Steering Committees, National Trade Facilitation Committees, Corridor Authorities and Joint Border Committees

title.narrative: Pharmacy and Poisons Board -Phase II

narrative.narrative:
1.	The Pharmacy and Poisons Board (PPB) is the Drug Regulatory Authority established under the Pharmacy and Poisons Act, Chapter 244 of the Laws of Kenya. 
2.	The Board regulates the Practice of Pharmacy, Manufacturing  and Trade in drugs and poisons. The Board aims to implement the appropriate regulatory measures to achieve the highest standards of safety, efficacy and quality for all drugs, chemical substances and medical devices, locally manufactured, imported, exported, distributed, sold, or used, to ensure the protection of the consumer as envisaged by the laws regulating drugs in force in Kenya.
3.	This funding is aimed at supporting the Pharmacy and Poisons Board in the following areas:

-	System Integration Support that shall enable PPB Information Management System interface with the Kenya National Single Window in the Import/Export and Port of Entry clearance process. This shall involve a system upgrade or enhancement of the Trade Affairs module within the PPB IMS.
-	System Integration Support that shall enable PPB Information Management System interface with EAC Regional Information Management System. The integration support shall include but not limited to the following areas:

a)	Information Sharing of the Medicine Registration and GMP Inspection registers.
b)	Joint Medicine Registration, Evaluation and approval.
c)	Joint GMP Application and Inspection

title.narrative: Mombasa Port Berth Construction

narrative.narrative:
The comprehensive TMEA-funded berths condition assessment and rehabilitation study observed that Berths 11-14, constructed in the 1950s to service conventional cargo, were in critical condition, with foundational piles and the underlying berth structure severely corroded, compromising the safety of users. Furthermore, the berths are increasingly being used for container handling although they do not have the requisite equipment such as ship -to-shore gantry cranes. Consequently, only vessels with their own ship cranes use these berths, leading to low berth productivity levels. The berths originally were also equipped with warehouse facilities alongside the quayside. KPA has since removed the warehouses and paved the yards behind these Berths providing limited container yard storage capacity.  The Berth 11-14 construction, part of Mombasa Port Productivity Improvement Programme Phase 2, will seek to increase KPA’s container handling capacity; catalyse an increase in KPA’s productivity levels by more than 20% to support the growing trade and creation of employment in East Africa and stimulate a reduction in the relative intensity in tC02 per tonne of cargo. 

The Mombasa Port Productivity Improvement Programme will implement a combination of infrastructure and productivity related interventions will be implemented. These will include the expansion of Mombasa county port access roads; construction supervision of berths 11-14; improvement of traffic flow and port access; a financial & cost-benefit analysis Study (Port Tariff Review); capacity Building for Critical Functions within KPA and Bandari College restructuring; Additional PIP activities supported by KPA.

title.narrative: Mombasa Port Productivity Improvement Programme

narrative.narrative:
The developments so far undertaken by KPA and TMEA have led to improvements, but the port still faces service delivery challenges. These include low labour productivity, poor cargo off take by rail and road, cargo clearance delays, lack of full automation, operational wastages and poor resource utilization. 

Specifically, the Mombasa Port Programme Phase 2 will seek to increase KPA’s container handling capacity; catalyse an increase in KPA’s productivity levels by more than 20% to support the growing trade and creation of employment in East Africa and stimulate a reduction in the relative intensity in tC02 per tonne of cargo. 

A combination of infrastructure and productivity related interventions will be implemented. These will include expansion of Mombasa county port access roads; construction supervision of berths 11-14; Improve Traffic flow and Port access; Financial & Cost-Benefit Analysis Study (Port Tariff Review); Capacity Building for Critical Functions within KPA and Bandari College restructuring; Additional PIP activities supported by KPA.
TradeMark East Africa

title.narrative: Mombasa West Integrated Urban Roads Network

narrative.narrative:
Works and consultancy services for expansion of Mombasa West Integrated Urban Roads Network Project

The Port of Mombasa is the principal gateway to the Eastern African region and serves a wide hinterland including the EAC countries of Kenya, Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi and Northern Tanzania. The efficiency of the Port therefore has a major impact on the economies of the countries it serves and can unlock the region’s growth potential. However, if underdeveloped and with poor road access, it will remain a key constraint to trade and economic growth of the region.

The Mombasa West Integrated Urban Roads Network Project will be implemented in phases, the first of which is already approved and underway (expansion of Port Reitz Road and Airport Road). The proposed second and third phases will include: provision of an additional lane on either side of Kipevu Road and improvement of the existing two lanes on either side; modification of Gate 18 to facilitate the provision of additional three lanes at Gate 18; expansion of Magongo Road section from the Shell petrol station junction to Jomvu; provision of a Mombasa Port gate truck holding ground and expansion of airport road junction through Bomu Hospital to link Magongo road through to the Refinery road up to the Mombasa Nairobi.  All phases will be implemented through design and build contracts.

title.narrative: Increased Market Access 4 Women-Owned Small and Medium Enterprises  -East African Women in Business Platform(EAWIB)

narrative.narrative:
The increased market access for women owned SMEs will increase the value of women owned SMEs in EAC regional trade and build ion the work done in strategy 1 . The project will seek to achieve the following objectives
a)	Increase market access for women owned enterprises using technology as a major driver. Lack of market access continues to hinder women from participating in international trade. The project will facilitate regional and international linkages for the East African owned women businesses. The project will seek to profile women businesses  in the region, conduct training on key areas where women lag behind such as packaging and branding, create a virtual market place for women entrepreneurs as well as conduct B2B linkage events where women can trade amongst themselves as well as meet large international buyers
b)	Improve the policy and regulatory environment for women in trade. The project will run very targeted advocacy campaigns issues that are best addressed at the regional level such as participation in the Common External Review process and lobbying for women’s access to government procurement opportunities across the region
c)	Strengthen the institutional capacity of EAWIBP to continue being the voice of East African women businesses at the regional level. This will involve hiring a programmes officer to support the market access activities and advocacy work as well as an ICT officer to support the virtual market place platform

title.narrative: Making Trade Work 4 Women in Rwanda - ProFemme

narrative.narrative:
The Rwanda programme has recorded significant success from the strategy I women and trade project specifically in the establishment of the cooperatives. This project will therefore build on this success and replicate good business models and lessons learned in the establishment of cooperatives for WCBT and replicate this for other segments like urban traders. Despite the significant results achieved in the ProFemme project facilitating women cross border traders in Rwanda to trade through cooperatives, other women traders continue to trade in low volumes and low value commodities and services which reduces the profitability of their trade. In strategy Il, this project will have a stronger focus on increasing trade in higher value goods so as to increase the trade value of the targeted traders/SMEs by addressing challenges faced in specific sectors/ value chains. The project will replicate the lessons learnt while the target group will be expanded to cover small and medium women owned enterprises to access export markets. The project specifically seeks to achieve the objectives below:
(i) Increase access to information and trade support services: Small business owners (predominantly women) state that the high tax burden in the formal sector forces them to operate informally. This is further demonstrated by the limited access to affordable finance for women traders. In 2011, 28.2% of women had bank accounts at formal financial institutions in comparison to 37.5% of men. Even where the Simplified Trade Regime is implemented, in order to benefit from the regime, an exporter must be VAT registered. Given that they trade informally, the majority are unable to meet this criterion. l The project will aim to provide capacity in terms of skills and knowledge to enable women in selected value chains to trade formally, improve access finance and markets.
(ii)lncrease trade value for women: The Rwanda National Cross Border Trade Strategy confirms that men trade primarily in capital intensive goods (e.g. manufactured goods), while women trade in commodities with little or no value addition and are therefore disadvantaged as their returns on trade remain low. The project's objective is to support women traders to access high value markets through trading in clusters/cooperatives and other groupings that support consolidation of resources and collective bargaining for cost reduction.
TradeMark East Africa

title.narrative: Supporting E-commerce Ecosystem

narrative.narrative:
TMEA plans to implement the Supporting E-commerce Ecosystem Development (SEED) programme that will support interventions focused on boosting cross border e-commerce through improved efficiency within the ecosystem. In the context of the SEED Programme cross border e-commerce is defined as the selling and buying, clearance and transit of goods from one country to another within the Eastern Africa countries.  										

TMEA will partner with key stakeholders in the e-commerce ecosystem system including national governments and the EAC secretariate, trade support agencies responsible for trade facilatation, Private sector service providers in logisics, payments, digital market places, postal offices	

In a bid to boost cross border trade in the region and facilitate greater market access, TMEA aims to rollout its Supporting E-Commerce Ecosystem Development (SEED) programme.  Proposed interventions under the programme will focus on addressing market, logistics, cross border payments and regulatory constraints across the region

title.narrative: Programming to Increase Role of Women in Logistics Industry

narrative.narrative:
Greater participation of women in an industry helps in improving the gender imbalance and provides an increased talent pool. This is especially true for East Africa’s logistics industry that is experiencing a significant skills gap in its workforce. However, there are constraints that hinder greater and meaningful involvement of women in the industry.  

This project consists of four pilot interventions that will be fast tracked as a precursor to a more significant and robust programme to address challenges faced by women in logistics. These pilot interventions at firm level are expected to catalyse industry-wide changes that will create a conducive and favourable environment for more women to actively participate in the industry.  The programme is anchored on career cycle models that can present holistic solutions to address the challenges that women in logistics face.

The programme is expected to lead to an uptake of women in the logistics sector and also provide the industry with a significant new talent pool at a time when the industry is suffering from a major skill gap.

title.narrative: East Africa Community (EAC) Logistics Sector Skills Enhancement Program

narrative.narrative:
In East Africa, there is a large skills gap in the logistics sector. To address this challenge, the Logistics Directorate in TMEA has designed a programme which seeks to establish an appropriate capacity-building programmes using a harmonised curriculum in the region to meet emerging demands as trade grows.

This project component will focus on building the capacity of smaller firms to effectively compete with larger firms in the market, by (i) providing capacity-building opportunities to improve the quality of logistics services; (ii) enabling access to credible data to overcome information deficits and building stronger advocacy; and (iii) creating third party logistics infrastructure to allow them to provide end-to-end services to their clients.

Specifically, the programme consists of three sub-components: 1) setting up a truck driver training programme; 2) setting up a warehouse operator training programme; and, 3) expanding the successful EACFFPC training to other regional economic centres.

The programme is expected to lead to increased efficiency in private sector logistics service provision for transporting and storing goods in East Africa.

title.narrative: Trade Logistics Information Pipeline (TLIP)

narrative.narrative:
In international trade the supply chain that links the process of:  producing, manufacturing, moving and marketing of goods in international trade involves several business processes, regulatory documents, border formalities and logistics from sources of production to destination markets or consumption centres is highly complex, multi-layered and information intensive. The more borders cargo has to transit through, the more challenging it is to move the goods from source to destination.  The associated constraints with this kind of supply chain requires the establishment of seamless linkages among the supply chain actors to enable them to act more efficiently and transparently to lower the time and costs associated with the international trade process.

The programme aims at developing and implementing information sharing and exchange frameworks based on ICT to improve the information systems used by different supply chain actors by giving them direct access to relevant information. This will result in optimal transmission and use of information, enhanced visibility, improved transparency and predictability, and ultimately increase efficiency in the supply chains used by EATN businesses.  It will also contribute to improved competitiveness of EATN trade and in particular exports.
TradeMark East Africa

title.narrative: Trade Sanitary and Phytosanitary (SPS) Framework

narrative.narrative:
The SPS programme’s goal is to reduce SPS barriers to trade. It will work with SPS regulatory agencies in the different countries to enable them to successfully carry out their mandate to enforce compliance to SPS requirements. It will also support private economic actors to increase compliance with SPS requirements for key markets.  SPS Agencies will be supported to carry out effective export inspections so that the certificates issued are deemed to be enough. Various economic actors such as exporters and producers will be trained to acquire product certification to access priority export markets. The programme will therefore comprise of:
1.	Supporting economic actors at the national level to comply to SPS requirements for their target markets
2.	Building the capacity of national SPS agencies to enforce compliance to applicable SPS measures
3.	Strengthening Regional Cooperation in developing and implementing SPS measures
Sustainability will be in-built in the programme to ensure continuity and impact after TMEA interventions end. This will be through staff training and building financial self-sustenance into the programme design.

title.narrative: Standards and Quality Infrastructure

narrative.narrative:
Over the last 20 years, there has been a drive towards tariff reduction under the auspices of the WTO. As a result, there has been a 15% reduction in applied tariffs, resulting in the current average tariff of 9% applied by WTO members. Given the substantial reduction in tariffs, focus in trade facilitation has now shifted to non-tariff measures that impede trade, and in many cases, have a higher impact than the tariffs. Non-tariff measures include discriminatory regulations, procedures and fees that are sometimes used in a protectionist manner. There is also widespread use of quality parameters (also referred to as technical barriers to trade), that go beyond the legitimate requirements, and have the impact of impeding trade. These measures include standards, product specifications such as product characteristics, production methods, packaging or labelling, and related processes that are used to verify compliance. 

This programme aims to create an environment that supports compliance to Standards and Technical Regulations, without necessarily creating additional barriers to trade. Its aim is to enhance the capacity of regulatory agencies at the national levels, such as National Bureaux of Standards (NSBs), Food and Drug Agencies (FDAs), and other affiliate agencies, to enforce compliance to Standards and Technical Regulations, while facilitating trade. The programme also seeks to increase product, process and system certification for firms and small and medium enterprises (SMEs) as a means to demonstrate compliance to voluntary and compulsory standards and technical regulations. Regionally, the programme will support cooperation in harmonization, mutual recognition and equivalence of technical regulations to ease cross-border trade in goods. This will be through regional interventions to address country-specific requirements such as testing, labelling and certification. 

In summary, the programme interventions will:
1.	Increase regulatory coordination at the regional and international level to reduce multiplicity of mandatory quality requirements.
2.	Improve the capacity of firms and SMEs to comply with Standards and Technical Regulations for relevant markets
3.	Enhance the capacity of regulatory agencies (NSBs, FDAs and affiliate agencies) to enforce compliance to set Standards and Technical Regulations
TradeMark East Africa
